body: I'm all for libertarianism, but how do you deal with climate change without implementing regulations?
body_html: I'm all for libertarianism, but how do you deal with climate change without implementing regulations?

guild.description:
Memes from a libertarian point of view. 

This guild has 0 rules period. It will regulate itself.
guild.description_html:
Memes from a libertarian point of view.

This guild has 0 rules period. It will regulate itself.
guild.name: LibertarianMemes

body: Theres a couple thoughts on how this would work from a libertarian perspective, one would be switching to renewables (by renewables I mean nuclear as wind and solar are not profitable without subsidies) because with less regulation and no government influence on the fossil fuel industry it wouldn't be as profitable. The other thought is that private corporations would not keep polluting out of fear for repercussions from thier consumers (boycotts or going to a competitor that actually takes pollution seriously and takes steps to decrease they're footprint. But the long answer is there is no ideal solution because america only accounts for 15% of the world's greenhouse gasses and countries like India and China are actually responsible for most of the pollution and American regulations won't do shit about that anyways. It's such a large scale and global problem theres not just 1 simple solution, especially with government corruption and other countries interfering.
body_html: Theres a couple thoughts on how this would work from a libertarian perspective, one would be switching to renewables (by renewables I mean nuclear as wind and solar are not profitable without subsidies) because with less regulation and no government influence on the fossil fuel industry it wouldn't be as profitable. The other thought is that private corporations would not keep polluting out of fear for repercussions from thier consumers (boycotts or going to a competitor that actually takes pollution seriously and takes steps to decrease they're footprint. But the long answer is there is no ideal solution because america only accounts for 15% of the world's greenhouse gasses and countries like India and China are actually responsible for most of the pollution and American regulations won't do shit about that anyways. It's such a large scale and global problem theres not just 1 simple solution, especially with government corruption and other countries interfering.

parent.body: I'm all for libertarianism, but how do you deal with climate change without implementing regulations?
parent.body_html: I'm all for libertarianism, but how do you deal with climate change without implementing regulations?

body:
The fully human caused aspect perhaps, sure. Obviously a very politicized and special interest concerned subject, also a spiritual one I'd say with how climate activism can serve as some kind of religion for people in spiritual bankrupt times.

Putting the tin foil hat on: alarm bell should go off when it turns out to be the former oligarchs now on the forefront of climate change and the proposal of a carbon tax managed by a central bank. Former oligarchs changing tactics to one that's better for establishing control and influence on societies. Every aspect of human life, from money, to energy, to the genome itself is what's being lust after for control.

Tin foil aside, direct environment is obviously something we have direct effect on as humans and should try to care for not to pollute. Climate however is something wholly different.

body:
Local level can have regulations for countering pollution in the environment. This isn't the biggest threat to free market. The biggest threat is fake debt money: fiat currency, senseless money printing; governement subsidising, gov loaning, bail outs, gov ensurance, high taxing, any damn financial regulations and micro managements. Ensuring our bank deposits. etc. 

Having physical regulations for protecting the environment doesn't mean shit compared to all these other types of governement interventions, yet people often cling to that type of argument against libertarianism.
body_html:

body: Human activities may have impact to climate, but I think it is wildly overestimated. If Climate Change is really as urgent as the globalists claim, they would be pushing for technology that actually works like nuclear. But it's clear that they are after establishing a carbon tax, which is just a huge wealth redistribution scam.
body_html: Human activities may have impact to climate, but I think it is wildly overestimated. If Climate Change is really as urgent as the globalists claim, they would be pushing for technology that actually works like nuclear. But it's clear that they are after establishing a carbon tax, which is just a huge wealth redistribution scam.

body: Something that also could be consistent with the situation, and what I know for a fact is how many (most?) regressives view this: the globalist leaders are also semi-incompetent and are slow to act and don’t know the solution, but they’re trying to do something, anything, as Band-Aids. Like a carbon tax. So nuclear could still be on the table for them, but they’re part of a slow-moving system, so aren’t there yet.
body_html: Something that also could be consistent with the situation, and what I know for a fact is how many (most?) regressives view this: the globalist leaders are also semi-incompetent and are slow to act and don’t know the solution, but they’re trying to do something, anything, as Band-Aids. body: the climate has been changing ever since earth started to exist. this has been proved scientifically and a mere google search will show you that truth. in fact, scientists in a few studies have gone far enough to say that if we stop all carbon and methane emissions, we would slow down climate change by less than 1%. so yes, climate change is real but we barely impact it
body_html: the climate has been changing ever since earth started to exist. this has been proved scientifically and a mere google search will show you that truth. in fact, scientists in a few studies have gone far enough to say that if we stop all carbon and methane emissions, we would slow down climate change by less than 1%. so yes, climate change is real but we barely impact it
